topic_details.topicName: Letters, digits and symbols based series
Total no of students in a row
Maximum number of students in a row
Yes / No or True / False Statement questions

topic_details.topicDescription: In direct questions, the candidates are given the elements and the relationship between them is marked with the help of the signs, <, >, =, etc. For example A>B=C≤D

The new format of inequality questions which is now being asked in all major exams is that they denote each sign with a symbol. For example, they may give “A@B, where @ means that A is neither greater than nor equal to B”. In this case, the “=” sign has been denoted with the “@” sign. This pattern is now being followed for all major Government exams to make the questions complex and confusing.

Any logical arrangement of objects or people either horizontally or vertically or diagonally is known as Linear arrangement.
Ex: The row of the travelers in a train, students in a prayer hall, etc.
In this arrangement, every object or person in the arrangement will be facing the center of the circle.
In this arrangement, every object or person in the arrangement will be facing outwards.

Complex arrangements are very similar to linear arrangement problems in terms of arrangement and properties. But unlike linear arrangement, where the objects had only one property – their positioning, objects in the complex arrangement have multiple properties.
Given below is an example of a complex seating arrangement:

Amit, Bharati, Cheryl, Deepak, and Eric are five friends sitting in a restaurant. They are wearing caps of five different colors — yellow, blue, green, white and red. Also, they are eating five different snacks — burgers, sandwiches, ice cream, pastries, and pizza.
In a quantitative tabulation, data is given according to quantifiable attributes like weight, height, income, etc.
In a qualitative tabulation, data is classified as per non-quantifiable characteristics like gender, color, name, etc.
Temporal tabulation shows data based on time or period like a month, year, etc.
In this type of syllogism reasoning, the conclusions must be 100% true. Conclusions which are 99% true will be considered as false.
In this type of syllogism reasoning when the conclusions are not 100% true but the two given conclusions are 50% true then the either-or case will be formed.
In this type of syllogism reasoning, statements and conclusions are given in the coded form. Candidates need to decode the statements and conclusions to find the answer.

In this type of syllogism reasoning, statements are given followed by the options. Candidates need to choose the set in which the third statement can be logically deduced from the first two statements.
In such questions, one person describes his/her relation with another person (this may or may not be related to the person with whom the conversation is being made).

To make the questions complex, blood relation questions are also being asked in the form of a puzzle. A piece of brief information about multiple people being interrelated is given and sub-questions based on the same may be asked.
The relationship between two people may be denoted using symbols. This has become a common method of asking blood relation questions in competitive exams, nowadays.

Either the words are arranged alphabetically (forward/ reversed) or numbers are arranged in ascending/ descending order. The arrangement is usually based on the first letter of every word. Sometimes it is based on the last letter of every word. Both words and numbers could be arranged individually or simultaneously in each step. The rearrangement can start from the left or right side of the sentence and sometimes even simultaneously from both the ends. The rearrangement could either start with a word or a number etc.

Some mathematical operations (like squaring the number, adding the digits within the number, some common number added/subtracted/multiplied/divided to each number etc.) are applied on the numbers in each step.

In this type the positions of characters/alphabets/words etc., in the input changes according to questions, following a particular pattern which repeats itself e.g. 'shift 1st character to last' or 'interchange 1st & last' etc.

topic_details.topicName: Basic Fill in the Blanks Format
topic_details.topicDescription: The simplest format for the cloze test is that a passage is given with multiple blanks and candidates need to choose one correct answer from the given options, which would be appropriate and logically fill the blank.

With the increased competition in the various Government exams, a new pattern for cloze test frequently appears in the examination. Instead of giving blanks,  multiple words are given in bold in the passage and candidates need to answer if the word given in bold is appropriate or if it can be replaced with another word from the given options

topic_details.topicName: Rearranged into a paragraph with fixed sentences
topic_details.topicDescription: the opening sentence and closing sentence are already fixed.
Questions are asked after the jumbled sentences. This type usually only comes in banking exams.

topic_details.topicDescription: Major categories of ratios are: compounded, duplicate and sub-duplicate, triplicate and sub-triplicate, ratio of equalities and inequalities.
There are four kinds of proportions, namely direct, compound, inverse, and continued.
This type is the easiest of all types of percentage problems. This is the same type of problem you would have seen in your school days.

topic_details.topicDescription:
A permutation is the choice of r things from a set of n things without replacement and where the order matters.

nPr = (n!) / (n-r)!

A combination is the choice of r things from a set of n things without replacement and where order does not matter.
nCr

topic_details.topicDescription: This is one topic from where the maximum questions are formed on this topic.  In this, It is necessary to consider the verb according to the subject.  As per the rules, Verbs should always be dependent on the subject or vice-versa.  For example- if the subject is plural then the verb should also be plural, and if it is singular, then the given verb will also be singular.

So this is one topic that often comes in the category of difficult questions because sometimes the idiom is used in the sentence and because we have a habit of finding errors, no matter what it says, we tend to think that this part can be wrong.

This topic can cause confusion as one of the most common problems is where to place them because modifiers can cause confusion or unintentional humor in a sentence when they are placed too far from the noun they are modifying.

This can be very confusing and we end up doing silly mistakes. Sometimes we don’t understand the sentence structure and go with the flow and end up comparing things which are not logical or equivalent.

Another important point is that Pronoun should always have clear antecedent. If it fails to do so, then make sure it should be replaced by a proper noun. Likewise, in the noun agreement also, a person or thing can’t take a plural noun or vice-versa.
Words have the same meaning or meaning about the same. Synonyms fall under this class.
Words are opposite in meaning. May be referred to as antonyms.

Words belonging to the same genus may also be called grouping because the relationship between the words is one of the similarities of certain characteristics. Example: animal – (four-legged beast), lion, elephant, horse stringed musical instruments – guitar, violin, bass
This refers to words that grow out of other words. Example: friend-befriend, friendly, friendliness, boyfriend, girlfriend
Words have exactly the same sound or are similar in pronunciation. Example: write- rite, right, wright ( homonyms), heteronyms cite- scythe (similarity, not sameness)

External and permanent memory. It is also known as a backup storage device.
Example:-Floppy Disk, Hard Disk, Optical Disks ( includes CD-ROM, WORM (write-once-read-many) and Erasable (can be erased and reloaded), Pen drives, Memory Cards

topic_details.topicName: Control Keys and Function Keys Shortcuts

topic_details.topicDescription: System software operates directly on hardware devices of the computer. It provides a platform to run an application and helps to run the hardware of the computer and the system itself. Operating systems, diagnostic tools, device drivers are some included in system software. These are mostly pre-installed on computers. Examples are Windows, Linux, Unix, etc.

Designed for user-benefit to complete different tasks. These are either pre-installed in the computers or can be installed as per the need. It includes word processing, Language processors, web browsing, translators, editors and almost any other task for which we install the software. Examples are Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Oracle, etc.

There are several types of operating systems that work on different hardware and are classified as:
Single User Operating System:
Only one user can use at a time. Example: Windows 9X and MS-DOS.

Multi-User Operating System: 
Multiple users can access the computer concurrently. Example: Linux, Windows 2000/7, and Unix.

Multitasking Operating System: 
Concurrently more than one process can be executed. Example: Linux, Windows 95, and Unix.

Preemptive Multitasking Operating System: 
Through predefined criteria, the computer program can share underlying hardware resources and operating system. Example: OS/2 and Windows 95/NT.

Cooperative Multitasking Operating System: 
Each program can control the CPU as long as it needs, in this operating system. Example: MS Window 3-x, Mac OS, etc.

Real-Time Operating System: 
They quickly and predictably respond to the events in a predetermined time. Example: Lynx, OS, and HP-RT.

Embedded Operating System: 
The operating system which is self-contained in the device and is resident in ROM. Example: Minix-3, Windows CE, etc.

Batch Processing Operating System: 
Several jobs are executed together in this kind of operating system.

Distributed Operating System: 
The data is stored in multiple locations and can be easily stored.

The operating system has various functions that manage resources attached to a computer system. 

Process Management: 
This helps with activities of planning, process performance, and monitoring. 

Memory Management: 
It helps with the allocation and deallocation of main memory.

File Management: 
It manages files on storage devices and transfers from one device to another.

Input/ Output Management: 
It helps in assigning and coordinating different input and output devices with computers.

Storage Management: 
It improves the performance of data resources in a computer.
A network is connected to two or more computers through cables, radio waves, satellites, or telephone lines. It helps in exchanging files among these systems and allows digital communication.
This type of network is geographically limited to a small, local area and helps in sharing databases, files, and resources. For example- A computer lab in an office or school.
This is a much larger network that expands to a large geographical space such as state, country, or the world.
A network's topology signifies the types of arrangements or structures used to connect the computer systems—for example- Star network, ring network, or bus network.
A network terminal signifies any digital equipment connected to a network like a computer, ATM, and PNR machines.
This is a commonly used LAN technology that helps to format the transmission data, which is sent to other devices in the same network.
This is the protocol or principles that help relay packets of data across the boundaries of a network. This is what helps form the Internet.
